data.profileText: a Representative from Mississippi; born in Massachusetts, ca. 1795; completed preparatory studies; moved to Mississippi and taught school in Copiah County, Miss.; studied law; admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Westville, Miss.; held various local offices; member of the Mississippi state house of representatives; founded the town of Pittsburg (now part of Grenada); elected as a Jacksonian candidate to the Twenty-second and Twenty-third Congresses (March 4, 1831-March 3, 1835); unsuccessful candidate for the United States Senate in 1836; died in Jackson, Miss., in September 1852; interment at Greenwood Cemetery, Jackson, Miss.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Miles, Edwin A. "Franklin E. Plummer: Piney Woods Spokesman of the Jackson Era." Journal of Mississippi History 14 (1952): 11-34.

recordLocation.name: Mississippi Department of Archives and History
